Description: Mould-made pottery lamp with a flat bowl-like body, a slightly concave base, a short splayed nozzle, and a side-handle of vertical ring-form, decorated on top with a knotted double loop pattern, separated by a central groove. The slightly concave discus has seven oil-holes, one central and six near the edge. The discus edge is decorated with a band of egg-and-dart pattern between two moulded rings. Red-brown Nile silt fabric.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel from Naukratis in Boston MFA (11.45917). Ptolemaic parallels in the Library of Alexandria Museum (unpublished, from the building site of the new library) and in Cairo Museum (CG 26509, SR5/2055). Parallel from Herakleopolis Magna (Petrie 1905, pl.56, no. R.30). Ptolemaic(?) parallel from Schedia (Abd El-Fattah 1998, 51-2, fig. 26). Mid 1st century BC to beginning of the 2nd century AD parallel from Tell Atrib (Młynarczyk 2012, type TA 11.23). Abd El-Fattah, A. 1998. Recent discoveries in Alexandria and the Chora, in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 37-53. Młynarczyk, J. 2012. Tell Atrib 1985-1995. Vol. 3: Terracotta oil lamps. Varsovie: Éditions Neriton. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1905, Roman Ehnasya (Herakleopolis Magna), 1904, London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.062) (Phase 3)
